Mud Creek, N.Y., March 31—Bernard McHadden, the publisher, was
slightly injured early today when he
dived into water as shallow as his
editorials in the Young Men's Christian Association's pool here.

Mrs. Betsy Ross Rolloway, holder
of the Pulitzer prize for patriotism,
yesterday asked that the Hopkins
swimming team strike the Australian crawl dash from the list of
events at future meets, because "the
very name 'Australian' proves that it
is un-American."

Attendants helped him to a nearby
hospital, where he was treated for
scalp wounds and lacerations on his
forehead, nose and chin. Before leaving, he presented the nurse and interne who worked on him with back
copies of his La Liberte and the admonition to be wary of a Japanese
invasion on the West coast of the
United States. He said:
"You are young and do not, as yet,
fully comprehend the complexities
and sophistries of international politics. I'll give you two reasons why I
expect this invasion and expect it
any day now: first, Japan must have
an outlet to the sea; second, the
strike of the Geisha girls is by no
means over and the tired business
man can't wait indefinitely. Hollywood is full of beautiful girls. Get
the connection? Sure! Well, think
it over."

In a letter to Waldo Hambleton,
Blue Jay mentor, Mrs. Rolloway
asserted that it was "disgraceful for
American schools and universities to
teach our youth to be dependent on
things of foreign origin, when our
forefathers have developed such an
amazing variety of typically American strokes and dives."
"I have devoted my entire life,"
she added, "to the fight against the
percolation into our life of things
foreign. Italian spaghetti, Turkish
tobacco, French pastry, the Swiss
movement in watches, the Spanish
tango, the Viennese waltz, the Dutch
treat, Russian vodka--all these have
felt my wrath; especially, Russian
vodka."

auxiliary to the Dormitory Activities
Committee will be appointed in the
near future by Chairman Pinck.
Those desirous of serving are asked
to communicate with him.

Previous Spring Dances have been
popular affairs with the 'dormers.
Several years ago one was given on
a floor placed on the campus. The
usual program is to have the dance
in the Cumming Room. It will probably be the case this year, too. When
the Dance Committee is appointed,
its first duty will be to extract, as
painlessly as possible, pledges from
the dorm residents to pay a proportionate amount of the expenses. The
tariff will probably run about a dollar a couple. The fact that the dance's
presentation is absolutely dependant
upon the welcome it receives at the
hands of 'dormers' was made absolutely clear by Pinck.

VISITORS ARE STRONG
Lavender Invaders Hold Victory Over Strong N.
Y. Lacrosse Club
The crash of clashing sticks, the
whip of whistling passes, and thuds
of bruising bodies will feature the
1937 debut of the Johns Hopkins
hickory handlers in their initial encounter with the Lavender of C. C.
N. Y. Saturday afternoon at Homewood. This affair will provide a first
rate proving grounds for the current
lacrosse edition as the Gotham Club
represents a singularly well-balanced
ten.
The Blue Jays, with ten lettermen
available for the starting positions,
take the field with a veritable powerhouse on both offensive and defensive phases of play. Seven members
of the varsity have played together
for the past three years, and they
should coordinate with precise accuracy. Captain Pete Swindell and
Don Naylor resume their point positions with Johnny Ghinger at first
defense. Jim Triplett, Bill Vickers,
Myra Green and Bill Kenny, all prepschool luminaries, will fill in as
first
the
troopers
when
shock
stringers play out. Dorsey Yearley, Johnny Beeler and Hammer
Himes are the long-winded Indians who trot incesstantly up and
down field at the wings and pivot staCharles Mewtions respectively.
shaw and Herb Seigal understudy
these men. The close-in attack presents Tommy Dukehart, Norm Melvin and Jack Kaufman with Johnny
Kempton, Johnny
Enders, Billy
Waters, Frank Buch and Pete BernKahl
George
alternating.
helm
guards the nets for the Morrill ma-

chine, with Ferdy Passano, former
All-State from Boys' Latin, in reserve.
C. C. N. Y. Powerful
C. C. N. Y. has the best rounded
array of 'crossmen seen in recent
years in Knickerville. George Lenchner and Phil Gottfried stand out visibly on the Lavender attack, supported by Larry Raskin. Its midfield will probably need the most
watching, for Curran, Kent and Wienberger are the most consistent and
skilled of the invading horde. The
City College defense is well balanced,
with Silverman at the point, Gerbarsky at cover and Block checking
away at first defenseman.
The Homewood group, who invaded New York last year to discolor
the Lavender somewhat by a 14-8
defeat, are eagerly awaiting the resumption of relations. The visitors
showed considerable power in downing a strong New York lacrosse club
last week, with the markers at 11-9.
This is conclusive evidence that the
oncoming array has players on its
attacks who can hit the target steadily the first time out. This characterizes a fine lacrosse club.

Hambleton Drills
Track Candidates
Drilling daily since spring vacation, the track and field aspirants are
preparing for their opening meet
against Swarthmore on April 10.
Coach Waldo Hambleton is putting his cohorts through conditioning exercises to gradually work them
into condition. The speed demons
and field men are working out and
shown signs that they will have a
good season.
Need Field Men
With Baetjer, Graziano and other
capable dash men back in the fold,
the main need for candidates is in the
field events.
Conditioning exercises will be held
the rest of the week with time trials
scheduled for the following week.

Games Scheduled For Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday Afternoons
With sixteen teams competing for
the interclass softball title, the
fourth year of organized play directed by Reuben Baer has gotten
under way. The softball league is
divided into four divisions, and
games are scheduled for Tuesday,
Wednesday, Thursday and Friday
afternoons at 4:15.
Names Changed
Although the same teams are competing as in basket ball, the renaming of most squads make it appear
there are many newcomers. In the
Tuesday League the Tigers, Nightriders, Tech Hawks and Senior
Mechs will battle for the title. The
Wednesday League contains the
Senior Gas-Civils, Cardiacs and Nine
J's.
On Thursdays the See-Ease,
Literati, Junior Mechs, and Whirlwinds play. The following day the
M. J. All-Stars, Cement Mixers, Blue
Bears and Newcomers engage in con
tests.

Mud Creek, N.Y., March 31—Bernard McHadden, the publisher, was
slightly injured early today when he
dived into water as shallow as his
editorials in the Young Men's Christian Association's pool here.

Mrs. Betsy Ross Rolloway, holder
of the Pulitzer prize for patriotism,
yesterday asked that the Hopkins
swimming team strike the Australian crawl dash from the list of
events at future meets, because "the
very name 'Australian' proves that it
is un-American."

Attendants helped him to a nearby
hospital, where he was treated for
scalp wounds and lacerations on his
forehead, nose and chin. Before leaving, he presented the nurse and interne who worked on him with back
copies of his La Liberte and the admonition to be wary of a Japanese
invasion on the West coast of the
United States. He said:
"You are young and do not, as yet,
fully comprehend the complexities
and sophistries of international politics. I'll give you two reasons why I
expect this invasion and expect it
any day now: first, Japan must have
an outlet to the sea; second, the
strike of the Geisha girls is by no
means over and the tired business
man can't wait indefinitely. Hollywood is full of beautiful girls. Get
the connection? Sure! Well, think
it over."

In a letter to Waldo Hambleton,
Blue Jay mentor, Mrs. Rolloway
asserted that it was "disgraceful for
American schools and universities to
teach our youth to be dependent on
things of foreign origin, when our
forefathers have developed such an
amazing variety of typically American strokes and dives."
"I have devoted my entire life,"
she added, "to the fight against the
percolation into our life of things
foreign. Italian spaghetti, Turkish
tobacco, French pastry, the Swiss
movement in watches, the Spanish
tango, the Viennese waltz, the Dutch
treat, Russian vodka--all these have
felt my wrath; especially, Russian
vodka."

auxiliary to the Dormitory Activities
Committee will be appointed in the
near future by Chairman Pinck.
Those desirous of serving are asked
to communicate with him.

Previous Spring Dances have been
popular affairs with the 'dormers.
Several years ago one was given on
a floor placed on the campus. The
usual program is to have the dance
in the Cumming Room. It will probably be the case this year, too. When
the Dance Committee is appointed,
its first duty will be to extract, as
painlessly as possible, pledges from
the dorm residents to pay a proportionate amount of the expenses. The
tariff will probably run about a dollar a couple. The fact that the dance's
presentation is absolutely dependant
upon the welcome it receives at the
hands of 'dormers' was made absolutely clear by Pinck.

VISITORS ARE STRONG
Lavender Invaders Hold Victory Over Strong N.
Y. Lacrosse Club
The crash of clashing sticks, the
whip of whistling passes, and thuds
of bruising bodies will feature the
1937 debut of the Johns Hopkins
hickory handlers in their initial encounter with the Lavender of C. C.
N. Y. Saturday afternoon at Homewood. This affair will provide a first
rate proving grounds for the current
lacrosse edition as the Gotham Club
represents a singularly well-balanced
ten.
The Blue Jays, with ten lettermen
available for the starting positions,
take the field with a veritable powerhouse on both offensive and defensive phases of play. Seven members
of the varsity have played together
for the past three years, and they
should coordinate with precise accuracy. Captain Pete Swindell and
Don Naylor resume their point positions with Johnny Ghinger at first
defense. Jim Triplett, Bill Vickers,
Myra Green and Bill Kenny, all prepschool luminaries, will fill in as
first
the
troopers
when
shock
stringers play out. Dorsey Yearley, Johnny Beeler and Hammer
Himes are the long-winded Indians who trot incesstantly up and
down field at the wings and pivot staCharles Mewtions respectively.
shaw and Herb Seigal understudy
these men. The close-in attack presents Tommy Dukehart, Norm Melvin and Jack Kaufman with Johnny
Kempton, Johnny
Enders, Billy
Waters, Frank Buch and Pete BernKahl
George
alternating.
helm
guards the nets for the Morrill ma-

chine, with Ferdy Passano, former
All-State from Boys' Latin, in reserve.
C. C. N. Y. Powerful
C. C. N. Y. has the best rounded
array of 'crossmen seen in recent
years in Knickerville. George Lenchner and Phil Gottfried stand out visibly on the Lavender attack, supported by Larry Raskin. Its midfield will probably need the most
watching, for Curran, Kent and Wienberger are the most consistent and
skilled of the invading horde. The
City College defense is well balanced,
with Silverman at the point, Gerbarsky at cover and Block checking
away at first defenseman.
The Homewood group, who invaded New York last year to discolor
the Lavender somewhat by a 14-8
defeat, are eagerly awaiting the resumption of relations. The visitors
showed considerable power in downing a strong New York lacrosse club
last week, with the markers at 11-9.
This is conclusive evidence that the
oncoming array has players on its
attacks who can hit the target steadily the first time out. This characterizes a fine lacrosse club.

Hambleton Drills
Track Candidates
Drilling daily since spring vacation, the track and field aspirants are
preparing for their opening meet
against Swarthmore on April 10.
Coach Waldo Hambleton is putting his cohorts through conditioning exercises to gradually work them
into condition. The speed demons
and field men are working out and
shown signs that they will have a
good season.
Need Field Men
With Baetjer, Graziano and other
capable dash men back in the fold,
the main need for candidates is in the
field events.
Conditioning exercises will be held
the rest of the week with time trials
scheduled for the following week.

Sixteen Teams 'Vie Letter Awards
For Softball Title
Games Scheduled For Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday Afternoons
With sixteen teams competing for
the interclass softball title, the
fourth year of organized play directed by Reuben Baer has gotten
under way. The softball league is
divided into four divisions, and
games are scheduled for Tuesday,
Wednesday, Thursday and Friday
afternoons at 4:15.
Names Changed
Although the same teams are competing as in basket ball, the renaming of most squads make it appear
there are many newcomers. In the
Tuesday League the Tigers, Nightriders, Tech Hawks and Senior
Mechs will battle for the title. The
Wednesday League contains the
Senior Gas-Civils, Cardiacs and Nine
J's.
On Thursdays the See-Ease,
Literati, Junior Mechs, and Whirlwinds play. The following day the
M. J. All-Stars, Cement Mixers, Blue
Bears and Newcomers engage in con
tests.

At the meeting of the Athletic
Board March 19, letters were awarded to those who participated in the

winter sports. Six major H's were
given along with fourteen minor H's.
Those who played in the required
number of games in basket ball were
Captain Herb Seigel, Norman Melvin, Earl Cross, Carl Rasin, Harold
Zheutlin

and Demetrius Traggis.
These six athletes received the major
award.

Eight minor H's were earned by
members of the wrestling team. The
awards were to Bob Vernon, 118 lb.
class; Bob Linthicum, 125 lbs.; Sam
Rosenstein, 135 lbs.; Lincoln Katz,
145 lbs.; Ed Clautice, 155 lbs.; John
Edwards, 165 lbs.; Charles Barnett,
175 lbs., and Bill Lamble, heavyweight.
In fencing, Phil Small, Irwin Sherman, Walter Peale, P. Reed, Ross
and Davis secured the minor H.
Awards for swimming and handball will be announced later .
